trial_identification.studytitle: Identifying older people to prevent disability: the Brief Risk Identification Geriatric Health Tool trial (BRIGHT)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does a case finding process using the Brief Risk Identification Geritaric Health Tool (BRIGHT) tool in primary care prevent development and progression of disabiltiy in people aged 75 and over living in the community.

conditions.healthcondition: Hospitalisation of those aged 75+ living in the community
residential care placement of those aged 75+ living in the community
quality of life as measured by the World Health Organisation Quality of Life brief form (WHO QoL-Bref) of those aged 75+ living in the community

interventions.interventions: In primary care the BRIGHT tool, an 11 item self completion postal questionnaire is sent to all those aged 75 and older on thier birthday from their primary care practitioner. Active recall ensures completion. Those scoring over 3 on the tool are referred for geriatric services through a coordinated comprehensive community assessment and referral programme already available. They will receive the BRIGHT tool every year for 3 years.
interventions.comparator: control practice patients get usual care for three years. This involves usual general practice services and referral to geriatric medicine and support services on an ad hoc opportunistic basis

primaryOutcome.outcome: Hospitalisation rate measured by National statistical data
residential care placement, routinely collected data

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of Life, World Health Organisation brief Quality of Life Intrument (WHOQoL-bref)
physical function measured by Nottingham extended activities of daily living scale

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: community living, 75 years and older for non-Maori, 65 years and older for Maori participants.

trial_design.concealment: cluster allocation of enrolled practices involved contacting the holder of the allocation schedule (using computer generated randomisation schedule) who was "off-site" at central research centre, after all patients of practices had been recruited.
trial_design.sequence: 'computer generated randomisation schedule. Stratified allocation. by practice type, Maori provider, mainstream provider. And block randomised within the 3 sites of the trial
trial_design.designfeatures: cluster randomised trial, practices were randomised to intervention or control.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The BRIGHT trial aims to see whether health surveillance for older people using a birthday card with a brief functional survey sent by the General Ppractitioner (GP) will reduce development and worsening of disability. Three regions of New Zealand, Christchurch, Wellington and Tauranga will contribute patients and follow up will be for three years.
